captions.text: In Korea, you're gonna notice a lot of stands like this.
Now this is where they're gonna sell a lot of street food
and it's not just the hot dogs and sausages that we're used to from North America.
[music]
This is a full meal.
[roar!]
[music]
So if you're feeling snackish and you don't need a whole meal
you can come in and get some odeng, which is just pressed fish cake
on a stick
and when you order dokbokki. Okay. So, over here,
dokbokki. Okay? Mmm, it's a much heartier meal. So you'll be pretty full.
And I want to show you over here the proper names.
[music]
So this is called Twigum. We have yatchae, kimaree, ojingo, gogoma, and mandu.
And if you want a snack you can have some kimbap.
"Dokbokki dugay jusayoh. Ahh.
Twigum doogay.
Yatchae, gimaree, gogoma.
Hago mandu, gogoma, gimaree.
Neh!"
So this delicious piece of food here is kimaree,
and on the inside you have the same noodles used for japchae,
so it's like a sweet potato noodle and it's wrapped in seaweed
and then wrapped in batter and fried.
And it may not sound too great right now, but it is really, really delicious.
Then you have, this is kogi mandu.
So it's just meat and noodles...
it's been basically like a dumpling that's been deep fried.
Also really delicious.
And gogoma is just sweet potato.
And Korea has an abundance of sweet potatoes, and they're really, really good.
And healthy for you!
And the only difference with yours, Simon, is...
(yatchae) yatchae,
which is covered in sauce. It's just basically vegetables
that have been battered and fried together.
So if you do order some dokbokki and twigum
you can help yourself to some odeng mul.
It's just the actual broth from the odeng,
but usually it has like onions, and crab legs
and other really delicious things.
So then, right in the middle here you have Soondae,
which is basically like a,
same japchae noodles mixed with a little bit of meat
and put into sausage casing and steamed.
So, it's really, really delicious,
and you could also get sometimes liver and other...animal...organs
with it as well. I've had lung before...
which I didn't enjoy. But I did enjoy the liver!
Now! Here's one of the best parts about dokbokki:
see this ten thousand won? Watch what happens with it.
It's happening...wait...
gamsahamnida!
Four thousand won back! Essentially, Martina and I
are both completely stuffed, and it only cost us six thousand won.
Now look at the currency exchange rate; that's, five bucks maybe?
For both of us to be completely full.
Now that's a good deal.
Dokbokki can be very, very spicy.
What do you want to do now Simon?
I don't know. Maybe we could SHAZAAAAAAAAAAAM!
[music]
So today we're gonna take you to order some blaaaaaahhh!

comments.text:
It is probably true in other countries as well, but avoid street foods 
located next to tourist spots.  Since the vendors know that you are just 
visiting and won't be back anyways, they don't put much effort into the 
food.  They don't even have to worry about online reviews.  As usual, go 
where locals go for the good stuff.﻿

comments.author: jstyledipset

comments.text:
+jstyledipset I actually stayed with a close friend of mine in Yongin. Just

comments.author: Annie Harper

comments.text:
+Annie Harper Anyways, since you said you went to Korea, I'm just curious, 
where have you visited (Seoul, Jeju, Busan etc..)? Also did you stay in a 
hotel or where did you stay?
comments.author: jstyledipset

comments.text:
+Annie Harper I hate the fact that some Korean people eat dog, but it still 
happens, just rarely. You never saw it sold or advertised because they keep 
it away from tourist areas because they know it affects reputation. My 
mom's friend still eats dog because she is a singer and she says that dog 
makes you feel really energized so she eats it before every concert she 
does in Korea. Nobody in my family likes to eat dog, I think it's kinda 
cruel, because the dogs are beaten to death before being eaten instead of 
being quickly and painlessly killed. I hate eating dog because everytime I 
see it happen it reminds me of my dog, and many Korean people nowadays 
don't like it as well because a lot of Korean people own dogs now too. 
Again only like 5 percent of the population still eats dog, and they are 
mostly the older generation. Technically eating dog in Seoul is illegal 
because during the Olympic games in Seoul they didn't want to scare away 
tourists, but it isn't actually well enforced, it was only well enforced 
during the Olympic games, so it's not very hard to find a gaegogi vendor 
(gae means dog, gogi means meat). Thankfully, my apartment in Korea is in a 
neighbourhood with many pet owners and a pet store, so there aren't any 
gaegogi places close to it.
comments.author: jstyledipset

comments.text:
+Annie Harper I've actually seen dogs that are bred to be eaten in Korea. 
They don't eat like Golden Retrievers or any breed, they breed a specific 
type of dog to eat. I don't like this because I love my dog and I hate the 
thought of eating it, but you gotta embrace the stuff in your culture even 
if it is something you don't like.
comments.author: jstyledipset

comments.text:
+Annie Harper Also I wasn't the person who asked the original question so 
don't set the reply to me
comments.author: jstyledipset

comments.text:
+Annie Harper Yea it's not a widely practiced thing, but it still happens 
some time. I go to South Korea every year to visit my family. Before in 
your earlier comments you were trying to completely deny the fact that some 
Korean people eat dogs. I don't like the fact that they eat dogs, but I 
admit that it is something that used to be done but isn't as popular now. I 
doubt you know more than me, I can speak Korean and I was born in South 
Korea, I visit it every year, so how about you stop assuming you know shit 
about everything, since when did you know my entire life story? I never 
once suggested that I know everything but I hate people who act like they 
know everything when they don't. If you don't know the answer for sure, 
don't act like your an expert and mislead us with false information. I've 
never eaten dog before, but my dad has, and my mom has eaten by accident 
before as well. My mom was once tricked into thinking it was beef but she 
found out later after the meal it was dog, but this was when she was really 
really young and stupid (she told me she was like 3 or 5 years old at the 
time). As long as you know what cow and dog looks and tastes like you won't 
be tricked so don't worry
comments.author: jstyledipset

comments.text:
+jstyledipset but once again, it isnt a very widely practiced thing. And 
especially not in larger providences, where this crew is located. You 
generalized a whole ethnicity by asking your original question. I will back 
this country till I am blue in the face because it's a beautiful place full 
of ancient traditions and cultural backgrounds.
comments.author: Annie Harper

comments.text:
+jstyledipset Yes because both of you know everything as well. I would hate 
to say but as someone that has been over seas I havent seen it being 
advertised nor sold. By saying "How do you know you're not eating dog?" You 
are racially stereotyping a race based upon accusations on the internet. 
Have either of you BEEN to South Korea? No? Then shut up about it damn. I 
would say as someone that has been on many asian continents I would have a 
little more experience in that field. So yes I do know more than you do. 
Back the fuck off me
comments.author: Annie Harper

comments.text:
+Keiko Igarashi Yea there is nothing I hate more than someone who pretends

comments.author: jstyledipset

comments.text:

comments.text:
Eating something like dog is very traditional in Asia and it's been done 
for centuries. Those dogs that are used for cooking are also breed to be. 
Understand that eating something like dog meat is just like eating chicken, 
as in Asia it is looked at as another source of protein.
comments.author: Jacqueline Fong

comments.text:

there is still the small percent that does. I think dog eating may be more 
popular in China though

comments.text:
Well, okay then, brainy ass! Here are the OTHER links about consuming dog 
meats in SK. Since Wikipedia is so unreliable for you :)

https://awionline.org/content/south-korean-dog-meat-trade

http://koreandogs.org/

http://www.idausa.org/campaigns/dogs-cats/dogs-and-cats-of-south-korea/

They even have a fucking petition to stop the dog meat consumption:
https://www.change.org/p/south-korea-stop-the-brutal-torture-of-dogs-and-dog-meat-consumption

Next time, smarty pants, before you call someone 'ignorant', make sure 
you're not ignorant of the thing that your'e trying to defend yourself. 
Stop the nonsense blabbing online, Einstein :)

PS: I have a relative who lives in Yangpyeong, Korea. So I know what the 
hell I'm posting about :P

comments.text:
I fell in love with Korean roadside tents the first time I saw a Kdrama (My 
Name Is Kim Sam-Soon, aka My Lovely Sam-Soon, if you're curious). There's 
something of a siren's call that goes out to me every time I see steaming 
plates of food being prepared and served in a collapsible shelter. I think 
it's the juxtaposition of home-style food with surroundings that say 
"homeless." Serious question: Are there ever fights between vendors for 
locations? How would they be settled?
